template_info.description: Module 7: Planning for Capital Investments — quiz generated from user notes

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes a capital-budgeting decision?
options: How to schedule employees next week
Whether to switch to a cheaper office coffee supplier
Decisions involving cash inflows and outflows beyond the current year
How to reorder inventory this afternoon
questions.correct_answer: Decisions involving cash inflows and outflows beyond the current year
questions.explanation: Capital expenditure decisions cover multi-period cash flows that extend beyond the current year.

questions.question: Capital rationing refers to {blank}.
options: choosing among positive-NPV projects when funds are limited
selecting only the project with the highest accounting profit
questions.correct_answer: choosing among positive-NPV projects when funds are limited
acceptable_answers: choosing among positive-NPV projects when funds are limited
selecting projects under a limited investment budget
allocating scarce investment funds among acceptable projects
ranking acceptable projects when capital is limited
questions.explanation: Under capital rationing, firms cannot fund all acceptable projects and must prioritize under a budget constraint.

questions.question: The present value (PV) of $1 received n years from now at discount rate r equals {blank}.
questions.explanation: Discounting moves a future dollar back to today using the factor 1/(1+r)^n.

questions.question: A firm’s minimum acceptable rate of return used to discount project cash flows is usually related to the firm’s:
questions.explanation: The hurdle rate is commonly linked to the firm’s weighted average cost of capital (WACC).

questions.question: Which stream of cash flows qualifies as an annuity?
options: $500 in year 1, $600 in year 2, $700 in year 3
$1,000 every year for 5 years, received at each year-end
$800 next month and $1,200 twelve months later
questions.correct_answer: $1,000 every year for 5 years, received at each year-end
questions.explanation: An annuity has equal payments at equal time intervals; here, a level annual end-of-year stream fits.

questions.question: The present value of an n-year level annuity of amount X discounted at rate r equals X × {blank}.
questions.explanation: The PV of a level annuity is X times the PV annuity factor: (1 - (1+r)^-n)/r.

questions.question: According to the Net Present Value (NPV) decision rule, a project should be:
questions.explanation: Positive NPV indicates value creation at the chosen discount rate; ceteris paribus, higher NPV is preferred.

questions.question: The internal rate of return (IRR) of a project is the discount rate at which:
options: the project’s accounting profit equals zero
the project’s payback period equals its life
the project’s present value index equals one
questions.explanation: By definition, IRR sets the NPV of a project to zero.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT typically an investment cash outflow when evaluating a project?
options: Salvage value at the end of the project
questions.correct_answer: Salvage value at the end of the project
questions.explanation: Salvage value is an inflow; initial investment, added working capital, and higher operating costs are outflows.

questions.question: The present value index (profitability index) equals {blank}.
options: PV of cash inflows ÷ PV of cash outflows
present value of inflows divided by present value of outflows
questions.correct_answer: PV of cash inflows ÷ PV of cash outflows
acceptable_answers: PV of cash inflows ÷ PV of cash outflows
present value of inflows divided by present value of outflows
present value inflows / present value outflows
questions.explanation: When projects differ in size, the index normalizes value per dollar invested; higher is better.

questions.question: After-tax operating cash inflow from a $1,000 pre-tax inflow at a 35% tax rate is {blank}.
questions.explanation: After-tax inflow = pre-tax inflow × (1 − tax rate) = 1000 × 0.65 = 650.

questions.question: Depreciation affects cash flow via:
options: the depreciation tax shield equal to depreciation × tax rate
a direct cash outflow equal to depreciation expense
reducing the discount rate used in NPV
questions.correct_answer: the depreciation tax shield equal to depreciation × tax rate
questions.explanation: Depreciation is non-cash but lowers taxable income; the resulting tax saving is a cash inflow.

questions.question: The payback period for a project with a net initial investment I and constant annual net cash inflow C equals {blank}.
options: initial investment / annual net cash inflow
acceptable_answers: initial investment / annual net cash inflow
initial investment divided by annual net cash inflow
questions.explanation: Payback measures time to recover the initial outlay; it ignores time value and post-payback cash flows.

questions.question: The unadjusted (accrual accounting) rate of return is computed as:
options: average annual net income increase ÷ net initial investment
average annual cash inflow ÷ average investment
questions.correct_answer: average annual net income increase ÷ net initial investment
questions.explanation: AARR uses accounting income; a common modification divides by average investment to reflect capital recovery via depreciation.
